metadata.sermon_title: Being Glad About Being A Christian
metadata.sermon_start_end: "Thy disciples fast not," they said to Jesus. It was half question, half rebuke. Ever, people have associated a frown with religion. There is a certain suspicion on the part of many people if one who claims to be a Christian seems too lighthearted and merry. [...] We have only to keep faith with the bright visions the Lord has given us, and we may be sure that we shall come "to an older place than Eden / And a taller town than Rome." God has willed it so!

1_specific_bible_passage.findings: The sermon uses Mark 2:18-19 as a springboard for a general discourse on Christian joy. It fails to identify what is unique to this specific text (the tension between the old and new covenant, the specific role of the 'bridegroom'). Instead, it treats the text as a general 'keyword' for gladness.
quotes: The Master came back with the reply that is the text: 'Can the wedding guests fast while the bridegroom is with them?' It was to say that where Jesus is, it is joy like a wedding.
1_specific_bible_passage.improvement_point: Identify what is in this passage that is nowhere else—specifically the Christological necessity of the bridegroom's presence and the impending 'taking away' of the bridegroom mentioned in the subsequent verse (v. 20), which the sermon ignores.

2_exegesis_original_context.findings: There is almost no formal exegesis. The preacher does not engage with the historical-religious context of Jewish fasting, the disciples of John, or the Pharisees. The Greek nuances of the 'sons of the bridechamber' are ignored.
quotes: Those who thought they knew what religion was all about did not like the way the disciples of Jesus conducted themselves.
2_exegesis_original_context.improvement_point: Explain the theological significance of fasting in the Second Temple period to show why the disciples' behavior was a scandal, rather than just a lack of 'frowns'.

3_application_concrete_contemporary.findings: The application is broad and leans toward psychological encouragement. While it mentions national difficulties and historical figures (Chamberlain, Hitler), it remains somewhat general in its spiritual 'good feeling' rather than concrete ethical or congregational application.
quotes: Great national difficulties arise. The nation seems to have lost its confidence about the Republic's destiny...
It is what the Lord has done in your life that ought to make you glad, full of joy and good feeling through and through.
3_application_concrete_contemporary.improvement_point: Move beyond 'good feeling' to concrete ways the presence of the Bridegroom changes specific contemporary behaviors or church practices.

4_interwoveness_exposition_application.findings: The sermon is more of a thematic speech than an interwoven exposition. The text is mentioned at the start and middle, but the bulk of the sermon consists of illustrations and hymns that are detached from the specific mechanics of the Markan text.
quotes: The Master came back with the reply that is the text... It was to say that where Jesus is, it is joy like a wedding.
4_interwoveness_exposition_application.improvement_point: Use the text's specific imagery (the wedding, the bridegroom) as the continuous lens through which the contemporary world is viewed, rather than switching to external hymns and poems.

5_three_parts_misery_redemption_gratitud.findings: The sermon addresses misery (the 'swamps of sadness', 'old charge against us') and redemption (the 'charge has been dropped'), leading to gratitude. However, the misery is often framed as psychological depression rather than theological 'misery before God'.
quotes: There was an old charge against us, but, thank God, in Jesus the charge has been dropped...
To be sure, we all must camp near the swamps of sadness and sorrow and defeat now and again.
5_three_parts_misery_redemption_gratitud.improvement_point: Sharpen the definition of 'misery' from 'unpleasant times' to the radical lostness that necessitates the Bridegroom's arrival.

6_two_ways_seriousness_of_choice.findings: The sermon touches on the 'gladness of fools' and 'payday for folly,' suggesting a consequence for choice. However, it quickly pivots to a 'pie-in-the-sky' assurance that lacks the sharp edge of the 'two ways' Dekker demands. The possibility of being lost is mentioned but not applied as a serious present reality.
quotes: Many a fool is glad in the illusion that payday for folly will come someday...
He has promised that he will get us all the way.
6_two_ways_seriousness_of_choice.improvement_point: Thematically connect the rejection of the Bridegroom to the 'broad way' of destruction, making the choice for the 'narrow way' of discipleship more urgent.

7_christocentric_grace.findings: Christ is clearly the telos. The sermon emphasizes that joy is found only in His presence. It maintains a strong focus on grace as the basis for the 'cleared record'.
quotes: The gladness of a Christian is structured and situated around Jesus Christ.
Man has no life in himself, it is Christ who is his life. [Paraphrased by the sermon's focus on 'Jesus is mine'].
7_christocentric_grace.improvement_point: Ground the Christology more in the 'two natures' (the Bridegroom as God-with-us) rather than just a source of 'good feeling'.

8_depth_and_length.findings: At approximately 1450 words, the sermon likely clocks in at under 15 minutes. According to Dekker, this lacks the 'breadth' required for true homiletical depth.
8_depth_and_length.improvement_point: Expand the exegetical section (Thesis 2) to provide the necessary 'breadth' that allows the 'depth' of the text to emerge.

overall_assessment.summary: The sermon falls short of Dekker’s criteria primarily in its lack of specific exegetical depth and its brevity. It functions more as a thematic encouragement on 'joy' than an exposition of Mark 2. It relies heavily on external hymns and historical anecdotes rather than 'recreating the Bible passage into a new, current word.' While Christocentric in tone, it misses the specific 'truth found nowhere else' in the text.
strengths: Clear Christocentric focus where Jesus is the source of the described joy.
Adequate use of the triad of misery, redemption, and gratitude as a background structure.
Strong rejection of 'general' or 'idiotic' gladness in favor of a grace-based joy.
weaknesses: Insufficient length (under 20 minutes) preventing theological depth.
Lack of original language engagement or historical-critical exposition.
The application is often too general/psychological ('good feeling') rather than concrete/spiritual.
Fails to address the 'two ways' with sufficient seriousness; the tone is overly optimistic.
overall_assessment.final_judgment_according_to_dekker: This is not a sermon in the strict sense of Dekker’s definition; it is a religious speech about a biblical theme. It lacks the rigorous exposition of a specific pericope and the necessary breadth to achieve homiletical depth.
